entry.title: Writing a Lodash-like JS utility belt library

link.title: Writing a Lodash-like JS utility belt library

entry.content:
I prefer having my own JS utility belt library like they do it on Lodash and Underscore.js, say, a stripped-down version of it, then bundled together into global namespace as _.

Example 1

Use as typical _ utility functions

_.format('Hello {0}!', username);
_.kebabCase('Some teXt to Kebab case');
_.isblank(username);

Example 2

Or, do the same with mixin and prototype option

'Hello {0}!'.format(username);
'Some teXt to Kebab case'.toKebabCase();
username.isblank();

The first thing we’re going to need is a few utility libraries. Fortunately, GitHub has plenty of opensourced utility libraries. Lodash, Underscore.js, Angular.js code arn’t difficult to understand as Babel code. So, I can run a search in the repo and it’ll return all of the code snippets and function definitions. Then I can break out the scripts in individual JS files that are in and save them as my own utility belt library. All I need is a little polyfill magic with a namespace, say, _ and we’re set. Moving right along.

Next is Mixin. You can run all the scripts in a namespace and is slightly obnoxious if not available as part of the browser API or native JS object too. You’d be amazed how intense it is to enable both namespace and prototype options. Not only this require a Closure pattern, but you also have to emulate methods. @esamattis/underscore.string has mixin for String types. So I’m gonna go ahead and break out that same script and modify my utility script. Excellent.

Here’s the complete source code I pulled together as my own utility belt nano-library.

entry.title: Personal productivity
entry.content:
Here’s my deliberate efforts to keep dancing. These tools and apps are my personal preference and probably might work for you as well. Not going to lie, I may have literally let go of some of these for the preference of my employers and clientele.

Contents

  • Notes written in markdown using Paper app
  • Task tracking using GitHub
  • Todo list of ahaa moments using GitHub app
  • Reminders are always on a calendar
  • Emails are filtered using Outlook rules
  • Reading as in books are only on Audible app
  • Budgets are planned monthly using Google Keep

Notes

  • Written in markdown using Paper app

Previously used OneNote, Evernote, Workflowy, Dropbox Paper, and even Notion.

Task tracking

  • GitHub Issues for task and bug tracking
  • Milestones for road maps and sprint planning, and
  • Labels to categorize based on features, bugs, and whatnot

This is to keep a track of todos on various projects. Not meant to plan my daily routines. Previously used Trello, Todoist, and even Asana.

Todo list

  • :lock: Todos repository on GitHub
  • GitHub Issues for each todo item

It seems like a pretty fantastic idea in lieu of traditional Trello, Todoist, Microsoft Todo, Google Keep, and the like. You want to try out GitHub app on the mobile.

Reminders

  • Google Calendar

Previously tried Workflowy, Microsoft Todo, Trello, but it has always been a calendar when scheduling meetings, appointments, reminders et al. whether it’s personal or work.

Emails

  • Microsoft Outlook Rules to filter and process emails and meeting invites

You want to have a look at Scott Hanselman’s article on Outlook rules for processing emails.

Reading

  • Audio books purchased from Audible
  • Listens using Audible app while on the go

Credit goes to former colleague and a dear friend, @hasith, for showing how to keep up using Audible. I’m a snail-paced reader, still reads a chapter or two occasionally to get inspiration for fiction writing.

Budgets

  • Google Keep as a simple list of expenses with the budgeted amount

Previously tried many apps and even spreadsheets but that doesn’t seemed to work consistently for not more than a few months.

entry.title: Writing a jQuery-like DOM manipulation library

link.title: Writing a jQuery-like DOM manipulation library

entry.content:
I’d prefer to write my own code for DOM manipulation. Think of it as a stripped-down version of JS libraries like jQuery. I’m not going to write yet another jQuery library but I like the idea of having my own logic to manipulate the DOM, say, a mix and match of native browser API calls.

Example 1

Wire a click event to the <body> tag

var bodyEl = $('body');
$on(bodyEl, 'click', showContentIfRouteLink);

Example 2

Or, do the same with chaining and prototype option

$('body').on('click', showContentIfRouteLink);

The first thing we’re going to need is a lot of digging into jQuery-like utility libraries. Fortunately, all of them are opensourced in GitHub so I’m going to have to get all the pieces from individual repos that are in.

First up is an IIFE pattern. It encapsulates all my code and runs as soon as it is defined. So a little anonymous function magic code is all that is necessary to get started. Kids’ stuff.

Next is a Polyfill pattern. I can define all the DOM manipulation script required but the browser will pick them up if not natively supported. @Financial-Times/polyfill-library has plenty of polyfill code snippets. Moving right along.

Chaining is a bit tricky. Not only it requires a Prototype pattern, but you also have to search the native DOM elements too. There’s no way I’m going to go thru 100s of elements to bind the script one element at a time. So it’s definitely necessary to break out helper functions and modify that to bind in interface or abstract level. I’m not going to lie, you’d be amazed how difficult it is to find the pieces and if you bind the script to the wrong element, nothing works.

Here’s the complete source code I pulled together as my own nano-library for DOM manipulation.

entry.title: Writing vanilla JS snippets and examples

link.title: Writing vanilla JS snippets and examples

entry.content:
For the record, I may have code a few 100 lines of JS in the past decade but I’m getting all kinds of help from our friends at JS and VS Code community.

The truth is, JS has become inevitable. I need a library of helper functions and boilerplate code written with vanilla JS. Easy enuf, except I need a playground without having to install NVM and Node.js like they do on Codepen. It gives the whole thing a very Control Freakery feel since the development environment will be more implicit than, say, adhering to frameworks and tools to build and run from source.

The first thing we’re going to need is a modern web browser that ship with Developer Tools. I can use the Snippets and the Console for coding and debugging so a little copy paste magic is all that is necessary to get started with vanilla JS. Kids’ stuff.

Next is a free web host running locally. I’m not gonna lie, you’d be amazed how tricky it is to pick a node-based web server. Not only are there many frameworks like Fastify, but there are node modules with VS Code extensions like Live Server. There’s no way I’m going to do npm init fastify boilerplate code one at a time. So, it’s definitely necessary to break out .devcontainer.json and add the live server extension. Then I can create JS snippets with example static sites and the live server will preview on localhost for me. Excellent.

Here’s the library of vanilla JS snippets and examples I pulled together so far.

  1. Fog City Learning. (2017). DevTools Basics: Chrome Developer Tools Tutorial [Video playlist].
  2. Codes, J. (2020). How to set up Live Server and browser auto refresh in VS Code [Video].
  3. Mutunhire, T. (2018). How to start a node server: examples with the most popular frameworks [Blog] Stack abuse.

entry.title: Hello world :wave:
entry.content:
GitHub used to be my unicorn and now it is my bitch. I interact with GitHub daily, so why not use it for live journal? It makes more sense, at least for me. I’m that nerd :nerd_face:

The truth is I have tried out all those widespread of notes taking apps from Evernote to Onenote, Workflowy, Trello, Todoist, and even Notion. For the record they all seemed great but this is just my personal preference.

In case you were wondeirng, this entire site is:

  • Originally, a flavor of the Otto theme
  • Built and published with GitHub Pages Actions
  • Hosted on GitHub Pages, and
  • Developed with VS Code using developer container for Jekyll

And, this article amongst rest are written in Markdown with Paper app.
